captions.text:
I promised myself I&#39;d stop starting these 
reviews by taking the piss out of the title,

but I need to fall off the wagon just for this. 
Bananza really doesn&#39;t work for me as a pun.

That Z gets caught up on the end of my tongue 
like your mum&#39;s nipple piercings. &quot;Bananarama&quot;

would&#39;ve flowed better, but I guess you can&#39;t 
use that. Well. Maybe. Hey, quick show of hands,

does anyone still remember Bananarama? ... Urgh. 
Okay, I&#39;ll ask again in 10 years. Donkey Kong

Bananza is the second big exclusive title for the 
Switch 2 (and the first that doesn&#39;t have quite so

many &quot;hastily shoveled out for the plebs&quot; vibes as 
Mario Kart World) in which we play as Donkey Kong,

a big, stupid monkey who wants to eat all the 
bananas. Not much of a motivation, I suppose,

but it works better than most of the cast 
of The Last of Us 2. He&#39;s busily acquiring

bananas one day when he gets attacked and sealed 
underground by the machinations of an evil monkey,

a big, burly, blue-collar laborer monkey, and a 
weirdly sexy lady monkey who gives me upsetting,
unfamiliar feelings I&#39;d rather not explore.

Donkey Kong, who everyone keeps calling DK, 
which I keep hearing as &quot;Decay&quot; and thinking

that he&#39;s going by the pseudonym he uses when he&#39;s 
drumming for his 2000s Nu Metal band, must journey

through a series of Jules Verne-esque underground 
worlds to reach the planet&#39;s core while escorting

a tweenage version of Pauline as the two of them 
learn to work together and become friends. So,

how exactly this leads to the setup of the 
first Donkey Kong game in which Pauline had to

be rescued from Donkey Kong is interesting fodder 
for speculation, I think. Maybe that was after DK

had one too many daiquiris and Pauline was having 
a moment of late-teens rebellion against her big

monkey dad forbidding her from seeing her creepy, 
middle-aged boyfriend. Or maybe it was Mario

completely misreading the situation and Pauline 
was just hanging out with DK, screaming at full

volume a list of her favorite Beatles albums. 
Obviously, this raises a lot of complicated

questions about the canonical continuity of 
the Donkey Kong franchise, such as this one:

Who the fuck gives a shit about the continuity of 
the Donkey Kong franchise? He&#39;s a big monkey who

likes bananas. The only thing that matters is that 
Nintendo are apparently tossing their hat into the

arena of Hairy Dad Games, and fair play to them; 
they chose the best possible character for it.

In that DK is both hairy and a dad. Possibly. 
I never understood the whole Diddy Kong

relationship; maybe he&#39;s his catamite. But I must 
confess to not getting terribly invested in the

central dynamic of Bananza, probably because it&#39;s 
a bit one-sided. Personality-wise, DK is little

more than a big, stupid force of nature who wants 
bananas, and he and Pauline have all the chemistry

of a brick in a jacuzzi. She&#39;s wary of him for all 
of the first five minutes of their acquaintance,

and then they&#39;re best monkey pals forever. She 
does have an individual character arc, though.

She&#39;s nervous about singing in public. Which we 
know because she keeps saying &quot;Oh no, I&#39;m nervous

about singing in public&quot; shortly before she sings 
in public on multiple occasions throughout the

plot. So, when she has her big moment near the 
end where she overcomes her nervousness to save

the day with her singing, it falls a little bit 
flat for me. &quot;Lady, you&#39;ve done an entire fucking

setlist so far. This is practically the encore. Or 
did none of the previous occasions count because

it was to an audience of animal people, you racist 
bitch?&quot; Anyway, Donkey Kong Banana Farmer was made

by the same team as Mario Odyssey, apparently, 
and it fucking shows. Basically the same format.

Go through a series of themed mini-open worlds, 
marking progress by collecting MacGuffin items

with a little fanfare each time, and each 
world has a unique collectible that can

be exchanged for appropriately themed pairs 
of shorts. Where it differs is that firstly,

you have the option of running around completely 
naked, which would probably have drawn Mario some

funny looks, and you have the unique ability to 
punch your way through the terrain. Not all of it,

obviously, for fear of angry phone calls from 
the level designer&#39;s union, but enough of it to

lend the game a unique method of exploration and 
problem solving. I say unique. The first thing I

did was mine out a section of rock until it was 
entirely disconnected from surrounding terrain,

and when it didn&#39;t succumb to gravity, I 
was like, &quot;Fucking knew it. Pack it up,

lads. It&#39;s just Red Faction Gorilla.&quot; 
And if you haven&#39;t heard that joke yet,

congratulations on having successfully 
cut social media out of your life. So,

this is old, not particularly impressive tech, but 
never mind. The controls are mostly functional:

up button to tunnel up, left button to tunnel 
left, and I&#39;ll let you figure out the rest for

yourself. Things do get a bit wobbly when you 
are surrounded by destructible terrain. Tunnel

into a wall and the camera just doesn&#39;t 
know what the fuck to do with itself.

God only knows what direction Mr. Kong will move 
in if you press a punch button; it&#39;s like trying

to navigate a ball pit with a concussion. The 
terrain manipulation is best utilized by grabbing

lumps of concrete and whanging them at stuff. The 
game makes use of about every way grabbing and

whanging can be employed as a mechanic, including 
grabbing and NOT whanging so you can hold it over

your head to keep the rain off. There&#39;s a lot to 
like about Bananza, but about halfway through,

I had the idle thought, &quot;This feels a bit like 
Astro Bot,&quot; which was followed by the much more

active thought, &quot;Wait. I liked Astro Bot more 
than this. Shit. Now I have to articulate why.

I&#39;m always having to articulate all over the 
place. What am I, a fucking dump truck?&quot; There

are a few odd design choices in Donkey Kong 
Banana Boat that feel uncharacteristic of

first-party Nintendo. Slight wonkiness of 
the standard controls and camera for one,

and it feels like an odd choice that the game 
doesn&#39;t track or require a minimum amount of

collected bananas until you get to post-credits 
mode; the only reason given until then is

to acquire more upgrade points for the skill 
tree. A fucking skill tree. Amateur-hour stuff,

Ninty. A really standard and token skill tree 
full of not particularly tempting choices like

&quot;increase by 0.5 inches the average size 
of the bubbles you blow with your spit.&quot;

In short, there&#39;s a lack of tightness to Banana 
Hammock&#39;s design that gives it a certain carefree

charm but manifests annoyances along the way. 
It&#39;s mostly fun, but the final boss fight really

brought it down for me. After a whole game&#39;s 
worth of nice Mario-esque &quot;do the thing three

times and win&quot; bosses, suddenly, we&#39;re locked 
into a prolonged cage match with an annoying

damage sponge who doles out opportunities to hit 
him the way a German babysitter permits screen

time. And then, 10 minutes later, you have to 
do the whole fucking thing again, but he&#39;s got

a stupider haircut. So there&#39;s that. Also, this 
isn&#39;t a criticism, but does anyone else feel like

this game&#39;s a bit, erm... sexually charged? Not 
with anything to do with Pauline, thankfully, you

monster, but... well, firstly, it&#39;s the way you 
can only dress Donkey Kong like a male stripper,

then there&#39;s the unspecifically accented way the 
game goes &quot;OH, BANANA&quot; every time you pick one

up that made me think of the dialogue in German 
porn. And of course, the central game mechanic

that entails Donkey Kong transforming into 
various naked, burly versions of jungle animals,

like a really buff ostrich with massive pecs and 
perfectly spherical bum cheeks. Is it just me that

got a weird sort of Cho Aniki vibe from that? What 
do you mean, what&#39;s Cho Aniki? Go ask your dads.
